Ok, after watching the recent Scott Manly video I looked at the Slow Motion here: At 5:38 you can see some "yellow stripes" in the exhaust plume. So I think, combustion was beginning to become inhomogeneous at this point. About 5 sec later there ist a flame at one side of the raptor engine. Maybe - and I am speculating - a leakage in cooling system (is it methane cooled?) and Raptor began to self-destruct or somewhere in the region of the preburner/turbopump so that there was a power loss and a LOX underfeeding. This would explain the yellow plume and perhaps a little faster than expected landing (see Hoppers crushed feet). But nevertheless great success.


Or it was just the dust...when Hopper was approaching the ground the orange/yellow(ish) bright flame went from the bottom upwards. So maybe two different effects: 1) A little malefunktion in the Raptor 2) Sucked in dust which was heated and emitted light. Rihgt after liftoff you can also see a color change in the exhaust when Hopper traverses through its own dust.

That is almost certainly not a COPV from the top, they are not painted black, have only one main valve and in the SpaceX drone shot, you can the they are all there afterwards.
My guess is, that this is the structure/vessel were they mounted the RCS thrusters on and what we see, is two of them depressurizing the system, loosening the structure they are mounted on from hopper and then spinning it out of control.
I assume some bolts came loose through the vibrations, or maybe it was a bad weld, whatever it is, valuable learning for making RCS thrusters more secure on Starship MK.1

I still think what you just watched was more of a test for Super Heavy than Starship.  Think about it.  1) That tall tank being built next to the nose of Starship is probably going to be Super Heavy, it’s not the bottom half of Starship, it’s most of Super Heavy.  2) There is no need to be able to land Starship in the near term (and maybe never as far as Earth goes), it doesn’t have any capability of surviving atmospheric entry so why bother learning to land on Earth now.  3) Super Heavy will need to land on it’s very first flight.  4)  They obviously want to land Starship on the Moon (something it actually can do) and do it right away.  A test flight for landing Starship on the Moon will require 2 separate GNC control loops, one to fire (probably 3) engines to simulate the 1/6 gravity of the Moon, and the other to land it with a single engine.  Not sure of the reason for all the secrecy except to spring a surprise on everyone.  I’ll bet you that’s what’s going on.
